THE JEKYLL, A POLITICAL ECLOGUE. (BY THE AUTHORS OF THE ROLLIAD, &c. This poem is by Richardson et al. Jekyll, the wag of Law, the scribler's pride, Calne to the Senate sent, when Townsend dy'd. So Lansdown will'dâthe old hoarse rook at rest. A jack-daw phenix chatters from his nest. Statesman, and Lawyer now, with clashing cares The important youth roams thro' the Temple-squares. Yet stays his step, where with congenial play The well-known fountain babbles day by day: The little fountain!âwhose restricted course, In low faint Essays owns its shallow source: There, to the tinkling jet, he tun'd his tongue, While Lansdown's fame, and Lansdown's fall he sung. âWhere were our friends, when the remorseless crew âOf felon Whigs,âgreat Lansdown's pow'r o'erthrew? âFor neither then within St. Stephen's wall âObedient Westcote hail'd the Treasury-call; âNor Treachery then had branded Eden's fame, âOr taught mankind the miscreant Minchin's name. âJoyful no moreâ(tho' Tommy spoke so long!) âWas high-born Howard's cry, or Powney's pratling tongue. âVaid was thy roar. Mahon!âtho' loud and deep; âNor our own Gilbert could be rouz'd from sleep. âNo bargain yet the tribe of Phipps had made; âLansdown! you sought in vain ev'n Mulgrave's aid: âMulgraveâat whose harsh scream, in wild surprize âThe speechless Speaker lifts his drowsy eyes. âAh! hapless day! still as thy hours return, âLet Jesuits, Jews, and sad Dissenters mourn: âEach Quack, and sympathizing juggler groan, âWhile bankrupt brokers echo moan for moan. âOh! much lov'd Peer! my Patron! Model! Friend! âHow does thy alter'd state my bosom rend! âAlas! the ways of Courts are strange, and dark! âPitt scarce would make thee now a Treasury-Clerk!â Stung with the maddening thoughtâhis griefs, his fears, Dissolve the plaintive Counsellor in tears. âHow oft (he cries) has wretched Lansdown saidâ âCurs'd be the toilsome hours by statesmen led! âOh! had kind Heaven ordain'd my humbler fate, âA Country Gentleman'sâof small estate! âWith Price and Priestley in some distant grove, âBlest I had led the lowly life I love. âThou, Price! had deign'd to calculate my flocks! âThou, Priestley! sav'd them from the lightning's shocks! âUnknown the storms and tempests of the state, âUnfelt the mean ambition to be great, âIn Bowood's shade had past my peaceful days, âFar from the Court and its delusive ways. âThe crystal brook my beverage; and my food âHipsâcornelsâhawsâand berries of the wood. âBlest Peer! eternal wreaths adorn thy brow, âThou Cincinnatus of the British plough! âBut rouze again thy talents and thy zeal; âThy Sovereign sure must wish thee Privy Seal. âOr whatâif from the Seals thou art debarr'd? âChandos at least he might for thee discard. âCome, Lansdown! comeâthy life no more thy own;â âOh! brave again the smoke and noise of town: âFor Britain's sake, the weight of greatness bear. âAnd suffer honors thou art doom'd to wear. âTo thee, her Princes, lo! where India sends, âAll Benfield's here,âand there all Hastings's friends: âMacphersonâWraxallâSullivan behold! âCallâBarwellâMiddletonâwith heaps of gold: âRajahsâNabobsâfrom OudeâTanjoreâArcot, âAnd see! (nor oh! disdain him) Major Scot! âAh! give the Major but one gracious nod! âEv'n Pitt himself once deign'd to court the Squad! âOh, be it theirs, with more than patriot heat, âTo snatch thy virtues from their lov'd retreat, âDrag thee reluctant to the haunts of men, âand make thee Minister!âOh God! but when?â Thus mouru'd the youthâ'till sunk in pensive grief, He woo'd his handkerchief for soft relief; In either pocket, either hand he threw; When lo! from each a precious tablet flew. Thusâhis sage patron's wond'rous speech on trade! Thisâhis own book of sarcasms, ready made! Tremendous book!âthou motley magazine Of stole severities, and pilter'd spleen! Oh! rich in ill!âwithin thy leaves entwin'd, What glittering adders lurk to sting the mind! Satire's Museumâwith Sir Ashton's lore, The Naturalist of malice, eyes thy store; Ranging with fell Virtu his poisonous tribes Of embryo sneers, and animalcule gibes. Here insect puns their feeble wings expand, To speed, in little flights, their Lord's command; There, in their paper chrysalis, he sees, Specks of bon mots, and eggs of repartees. In modern spirit ancient wit he steeps; If not its gloss, the reptile's venom keeps: Thy quaintness, Dunning;âbut without thy sense, And just enough of Bearcroft, for offence. On these lov'd leaves a transient glance he threw; But weightier themes his anxious thoughts pursue: Deep senatorial pomp intent to reach, With ardent eyes he hangs o'er Lansdown's speech: Then loud the youth proclaims the enchanting words, That charm'd the noble natures of the Lords. âLost and obscur'd in Bowood's humble bow'r, âNo party-toolâno candidate for pow'r,â âI come, my Lordsâan Hermit from my cell, âA few blunt truths in my plain style to tell. âHighly I praise your late commercial plan; âKingdoms should all uniteâlike man and man: âThe French love peace; ambition they detest; âBut Cherburg's frightful works deny me rest. âWith joy I see now wealth for Britain shippid: âLisbon's a froward childâand should be whipp'd: âYet Portugal's our old and best Ally! âAnd Gallic faith is but a slender tie. âMy Lords!âthe Manufacturer's a fool! âThe Clothier too knows nothing about wool! âTheir interests still demand your constant care; âTheir fears are mineâtheir griefs are my despair. âMy Lords! my soul is big with dire alarms: âTurksâGermansâRussiansâPrussiansâall in arms! âA noble Poleâ(I'm proud to call him friend!) âTells me of thingsâI cannot comprehend. âYour Lordship's hairs would stand an end, to hear âMy last dispatches from the Grand Vizier. âThe fears of DantzicâMerchants can't be told: âAccounts from Cracowâmake my blood grow cold. âThe state of Portsmouth, and of Plymouth Docks, âYour tradeâyour taxesâarmyânavyâstocks,â âAll haunt me in my dreams:âand, when I rise, âThe Bank of England scares my opening eyes. âI seeâI know some dreadful storm in brewing, âArm all your coastsâyour navy is your ruin. âI say it still:â(but let me be believ'd) âIn this your Lordships have been much deceiv'd. âA noble Dnke affirms I like his plan: âI never did, my LordsâI never can. âShame on the slanderous breath! which dares instill âThat I, who now condemn, advis'd the ill. âPlain words, thank Heaven! are always understood; âI could approve, I saidâbut not I would. âAnxious to make the noble Duke content, âMy view was just to seem to give consent, âWhile all the world might see that nothing less was meant. While Jehyll thus the rich exhaustless store Of Lansdown's rhetorick ponders o'er and o'er; And, wrapt in happier dreams of future days, His patron's triumphs in his own surveys; Admiring barristers in crouds resort, From FigtreeâBrickâHareâPumpâand Garden Court: Anxious they gaze, and watch with silent awe The motley son of politics and law. Meanwhile, with softest smiles and courteous bows, He, graceful bending, greets their ardent vows. âThanks, generous friends! (he cries) kind Templars, thanks! âTho' now, with Lansdown's band pour Jeqyll ranks, âThink not, he wholly quits black-letter cares: âStill, still the Lawyer with the Statesman shares. âBut see! the shades of night o'er spread the skies! âThick fogs and vapours from the Thames arise! âFar different hopes our separate toils inspire; âTo parchment, you, and precedent retire! âWith deeper bronze your darkest looks imbrown, âAdjust your brows for the demurring frown; âBrood o'er the fierce rebutters of the bar, âAnd brave the issue of the gowned war. âMe, all unpractis'd in the bashful mood, âStrange novice thoughts, and alien cares delude; âYes, modest Eloquence! ev'n I must court âFor once, with mimic vows, thy coy support. âOh! wou'dst thou lend the semblance of thy charms! âFeig'd agitations, and assum'd alarms, âTwere all I'd ask!âbut for one day alone âTo ape thy downcast lookâthy suppliant tone; âTo pauseâand bow with hesitating grace, âHere try to faulterâthere a word misplace; âLong banish'd blushes this pale cheek to teach, âAnd act the miseries of a maiden speech!â FINIS.
